hints.label: def-coupled-cloning-expectation
hints.title: Coupled Cloning Expectation
hints.content:
6373: :label: def-coupled-cloning-expectation
6374: 
6375: Consider two swarms $(S_1, S_2)$ in the coupled state space (see {prf:ref}`def-coupled-state-space`). Let $(S'_1, S'_2)$ be the output swarms after applying $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ to each independently, using **synchronous coupling** of all randomness:
6376: 
6377: - Same PRNG seeds for companion selection
6378: - Same pairing algorithm random choices
6379: - Same threshold samples $T_i$ for each walker index $i$
6380: - Same Gaussian jitters $\zeta_i^x$ for position updates (when both walkers clone)
6381: - Same rotation operators $R_i$ for velocity collisions (when both walkers participate in collisions)
6382: 
6383: For any function $f: \Sigma_N \times \Sigma_N \to \mathbb{R}$, the **coupled cloning expectation** is:
6384: 
6385: $$
6386: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[f(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2] := \mathbb{E}[f(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2, \text{coupling}]
hints.raw_directive:
6370: To analyze the drift of the Lyapunov function components, we work with two copies of the swarm evolving under synchronous coupling.

6372: :::{prf:definition} Coupled Cloning Expectation
6373: :label: def-coupled-cloning-expectation
6374: 
6375: Consider two swarms $(S_1, S_2)$ in the coupled state space (see {prf:ref}`def-coupled-state-space`). Let $(S'_1, S'_2)$ be the output swarms after applying $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ to each independently, using **synchronous coupling** of all randomness:
6376: 
6377: - Same PRNG seeds for companion selection
6378: - Same pairing algorithm random choices
6379: - Same threshold samples $T_i$ for each walker index $i$
6380: - Same Gaussian jitters $\zeta_i^x$ for position updates (when both walkers clone)
6381: - Same rotation operators $R_i$ for velocity collisions (when both walkers participate in collisions)
6382: 
6383: For any function $f: \Sigma_N \times \Sigma_N \to \mathbb{R}$, the **coupled cloning expectation** is:
6384: 
6385: $$
6386: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[f(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2] := \mathbb{E}[f(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2, \text{coupling}]
6387: $$

hints.label: rem-coupling-benefits
hints.title: Synchronous Coupling Benefits
hints.content:
6392: :label: rem-coupling-benefits
6393: 
6394: The synchronous coupling ensures that:
6395: 
6396: 1. **Common randomness cancels:** When both swarms have walker $i$ in similar states and both make the same cloning decision, much of the random perturbation is shared, reducing divergence.
6397: 
6398: 2. **Worst-case expansion is bounded:** Even when the swarms make different decisions (e.g., walker $i$ clones in swarm 1 but persists in swarm 2), the expansion is controlled by the maximum displacement $D_{\text{valid}}$.
